misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each number with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers is present.
Output message reports 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this problem and a different textbook-style problem about computing average acceleration, leading to ignoring the specified task of summing even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the processing steps (loop, even check with n % 2 == 0, accumulation), and the required output format before starting to code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program solves a completely different problem (average acceleration) with different inputs and output text, and contains none of the required elements (5 integers, loop, even-number check).

evidence.note: The code reads three double values labeled v0, v1, and t, computes average acceleration, and prints 'The average acceleration', which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers and sum the even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration with inputs v0, v1, and t) instead of the requested problem (calculating the sum of five even numbers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a problem related to physics/acceleration, as indicated by the class name, variable names, and calculation logic, completely ignoring the stated prompt about summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading exactly 5 integers and accumulating the sum of only those numbers that are even.
symptoms: Code solves an unrelated problem
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Performs division and subtraction instead of summation and modulus checks
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely pasted or wrote code for a different assignment or example they found, or grossly misunderstood the entire problem description.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the assignment prompt carefully and ensure your code addresses the specific requirements: reading five integers, using a loop structure, checking for even numbers using the modulus operator (%), and accumulating the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names (v0, v1, t), and calculation (`(v1 - v0) / t`) are a perfect match for an average acceleration problem, confirming a complete misinterpretation of the 'Sum of Even Numbers' prompt.

evidence.note: The class name itself indicates a different problem domain.
The program prompts for and reads three 'double' variables (v0, v1, t) related to acceleration instead of five integers.
The core logic calculates acceleration (a) instead of summing numbers.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating acceleration (physics formula) instead of summing even numbers from 5 integers as specified in Q1.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving an acceleration calculation problem (a = (v1 - v0) / t) rather than the sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q1 requires reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of only the even-numbered values. The problem is about filtering and accumulation, not physics calculations.
symptoms: Code reads only 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Uses physics acceleration formula instead of modulo operator for even checking
Output message talks about acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the assignment, copied code from a different problem, or submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q1 carefully. The task requires: (1) reading 5 integers in a loop, (2) checking if each number is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulating the sum of even numbers only, (4) printing the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence because the submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with no relation to the sum of even numbers requirement. The code reads 3 doubles for a physics formula, not 5 integers for filtering.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers as required by Q1

evidence.snippet:
double a = (v1 - v0) / t;
        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + a);
evidence.note: Uses physics acceleration formula (a = (v1 - v0) / t) instead of filtering and summing even numbers
Class name suggests this is an acceleration problem, not a sum of even numbers problem

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different physics problem instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t rather than summing the even numbers among 5 integers, indicating a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), sum only those even numbers, and print the resulting sum.
symptoms: The prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
The program reads three double values rather than five integers.
The core computation is (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing selected inputs.
There is no loop, no even-number check, and no accumulator for the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion from a different textbook or lab exercise about average acceleration, leading to copying or reusing that template instead of implementing the specified sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and list the required inputs, processing steps (loop, conditions), and outputs. Verify that your variable names, prompts, and formulas match the current question rather than another example you remember.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program—prompt, variables, formula, and output message—matches the classic average acceleration example and contains none of the required elements (5 integers, loop, even check, sum), strongly indicating the problem was misinterpreted.

evidence.note: The program reads three doubles labeled v0, v1, and t and computes average acceleration, not a sum of even numbers from 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (a physics formula) instead of the requested task, which was calculating the sum of 5 even integers. This suggests a profound misunderstanding or negligence regarding the assignment prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program to calculate acceleration, or perhaps submitted code for the wrong assignment entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct task was to read 5 numerical inputs and use conditional logic (modulus operator) within a loop structure to identify and sum only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code calculates 'The average acceleration'
Variables are named 'v0', 'v1', and 't'
Input reading only processes 3 inputs of type double, not 5 integers
Does not contain a loop or conditional logic for checking parity
misconceptions.root_cause: The student failed to read the specific requirements of the assigned question (Q1. Sum of Even Numbers) and implemented a solution for an entirely different problem, potentially based on a previous or unrelated exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully reread the assignment prompt for 'Sum of Even Numbers' and align the code structure (input count, data types, use of loops and conditionals) with the required functionality.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code addresses a totally different mathematical problem (acceleration calculation) from the requested task (sum of even numbers), resulting in 0 points for every rubric category.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates acceleration instead of the sum of even numbers. This represents a complete failure to meet the requirements.

misconceptions.name: Mismatched Input Count and Type
misconceptions.description: The assignment required reading 5 integers. The student's implemented code reads only 3 inputs and treats them as floating-point numbers (`double`) using `nextDouble()`.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task required reading inputs v0, v1, and t as doubles.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading 5 inputs, and since they are integers ('Sum of Even Numbers'), they should be read using `nextInt()`.
symptoms: Only three `nextDouble()` calls are present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Stemming from the primary misconception (wrong problem solved), the mechanics of input reading also fail to match the specified quantity and data type (3 doubles vs 5 integers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you read the correct number of inputs (5) and use the `nextInt()` method for integer input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Direct observation of the code reading 3 doubles instead of 5 integers.

evidence.note: Reads 3 inputs using nextDouble(), contrary to the requirement of 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Wrong Assignment Solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that solves a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (summing even numbers from 5 user inputs).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving an acceleration/physics problem, or has completely misunderstood the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), and summing only those even values before printing the result.
symptoms: Code reads only 3 inputs instead of 5
Inputs are doubles instead of integers
No loop to process multiple numbers
No conditionals for even/odd checking
Calculation is acceleration formula, not sum of evens
Sample run is about physics, not even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have worked on the wrong problem entirely, possibly confusing this assignment with a different one or not reading the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully again. Create a loop that reads 5 integers. Inside the loop, use 'if (number % 2 == 0)' to check if each number is even. Accumulate the sum of only the even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap with the assigned task. The student provides an acceleration calculation when asked for a sum of even numbers.

evidence.note: This is an acceleration calculation problem, completely different from the assigned 'sum of even numbers' task.
